Award.AwardTitle: Temperature, seasonality and recurrent insect outbreaks - Tortix moths as a new mathematical and empirical model system
Award.AbstractNarration:
Instability of populations of animals, manifested as sudden outbreaks and crashes in their numbers, can have major effects on whole ecological systems. This project will build on recent discoveries in insects to investigate how temperature and the life history traits of a species can interact to change the timing of life cycles and the amplitude of changes in population size. The effort will combine sophisticated mathematical modeling, time-series analysis of existing data, and lab experiments to obtain a deep understanding of how temperature impacts the dynamics of populations of a tortrix moth. The investigators will test the hypothesis that warmer temperatures and more extreme seasonality favor outbreaks of insects by accelerating and synchronizing their development, such that multiple, overlapping population cycles combine to form a single, less stable cycle.


Tortrix moths are ubiquitous agricultural pests of high-value fruit, berry and nut crops. Findings from this project will enhance the ability of farmers and land managers to forecast outbreaks of these pests and to identify the life stages at which they can be most easily controlled. The broader impacts of this project also include the training of two graduate students and at least three undergraduates, and development of an international scientific collaboration between the U.S. and Canada. Findings will be disseminated to the public through agricultural extension materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tortricid insects are ubiquitous pests of all agricultural crops in the US and worldwide. Many of the most important of these have multiple generations per year and because only a subset of the life stages are susceptible to pest management it is important to understand and predict the timing of the life-cycle. Insect development depends inextricably on temperature; This timing thus depends on mean, variance and seasonality in temperature. In the research we used a 3-pronged experimental, statistical and mathematical approach to advance our ability to predict insect outbreak dynamics. Experimentally we studied laboratory populations at a range of controlled temperatures to characterize its effect of survival, fecundity, development and population dynamics. We used time series analysis to characterize the dynamics of highly-resolved multi-decade monitoring of tortricid pests in Pennsylvania and Japan. Finally, we developed and parameterized a new suite of mathematical models to predict outbreak dynamics from historical and/or real-time temperature records. In addition to its relevance to agriculture, an associated graduate project showed that the mathematical formalism can be used to predict mosquito dynamics and risk of vector-born infections. The project has resulted in several papers in the scientific literature, a textbook on modeling and analysis of outbreak data. In addition our work is incorporated in `Epidemics’ Massive Open Online Course with more than 30,000 registered learners from 182 different countries during the last 3 years.  In addition, we ran workshops and worked with extension agents in Pennsylvania and Japan to facilitate communication of our results to the public.  The funding supported the training and research of two doctoral students, three undergraduate honors students and a research technician.
